awd_titl_txt: Travel: Student Attendance Award for ISCAS 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal requests funding to support a number of US-based students for attending the 59th version of the annual IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems (ISCAS) with the intention of exposing them to the discipline and to encourage them to pursue careers in emerging issues in the area of Circuits and Systems research. Participation in this symposium is considered an important part of the graduate-school experience of students in computer engineering, providing the opportunity to interact with senior researchers and to be exposed to leading-edge work in the field. The support will enable dissemination of scientific knowledge to students who would otherwise not have the experience. This student-travel support will also facilitate the development of promising graduate students and will indirectly help train the workforce of the future in the key areas of computer engineering, in general, and Semiconductor Microelectronics in particular. Participation of women and members of underrepresented populations will be given due consideration for receiving support through this grant.

The International Symposium on Circuits and Systems (ISCAS) for more than 50 years has been the premier conference where emerging trends and novel concepts of Circuits and Systems research have been explored. The 2023 edition of this conference will address key trends and challenges in these areas and includes Keynote and Plenary Talks, Technical Paper Sessions, Tutorials, Panels, and Special Sessions. The conference committee has set up adequate evaluation criteria to select qualified students from a pool of applicants formed via open advertisement. While the requested funds will primarily be used for supporting graduate students, the committee may also consider US-based undergraduate applicants and post-docs in order to better reach a diverse population of potential researchers in this field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: DES AUTO FOR MICRO & NANO SYST

por.por_cntn:
ISCAS 2023 was held in Monterey May 21-25. The IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems (ISCAS) is the flagship conference of the IEEE Circuits and Systems (CAS) Society and the world’s premiere forum for researchers in the active fields of theory, design and implementation of circuits and systems. This is accomplished through technical conference sessions, poster sessions, live demonstration sessions, and publication of conference papers. The conference was a great success with 940 attendees. 1266 papers were submitted of which 666 were accepted and presented. Six superb keynotes were presented by leaders in the field (including the then-director of the NSF Directorate on Computer and Information Science and Engineering, Prof. Margaret Martonosi). The attendance was international with delegates from US, Asia/Pacific. Europe, Latin America and Middle East. A majority of the attendance were students from Universities from the US and Abroad.

A proposal was submitted to the NSF to support the travel to and attendance of the conference for selected top-ranked US students. The total budget set aside was $15K. Upon review of the proposal, the requested amount was granted. The conference is grateful to the NSF for this support.

Unfortunately, the late submission of the proposal as well as the subsequent delay in the approval and granting process made it impossible for the conference leadership to get the process in place to seek and grant applications for the travel awards. Hence, NO awards were granted and NO money was spent. The granted $15K, which was deposited in the accounts of Prof. Rabaey, the General Chair of the conference, was subsequently returned to the NSF. This was unfortunate as the support of the Science Foundation for this conference, which represents the cutting edge of research in the Circuits and Systems domain, was greatly appreciated. The necessary steps were taken to ensure that the whole process of application and awarding of travel grants would start a lot earlier and allow for plenty of leeway in the process.  

 


Last Modified: 02/25/2025
Modified by: Jan Rabaey
